Partners involved *: UNHCR Innovation Service, UN Global Pulse, Essex University Big Data & Technology Centre, Omdena Foundation
Description: Jetson is experimenting with two methods: gravity model and multivariate TSA, machine learning-based (open source, Python and R applications). The target variable is forced displacement, and the nexus between displacement, climate/weather anomalies and changes and violent conflict. The model predicts at least one month of forced displacement movement (population flow, influx-only). This is the arrivals of IDPs and Refugees in the different regions of Somalia (admin level 1) and the southern border region of Ethiopia (Dollo Ado).
Topic *: Affected people: Internally displaced persons;  Refugees and persons of concern
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Additional documentation: Official Website

Model name: Unaccompanied and separated children projection model
Partners involved *: UNHCR, University of East Anglia
Geographical scope *: South Sudan, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Somalia
Description: Arrivals of unaccompanied and separated children in refugee settings. The outcome is a prediction of the number of arrivals of Unaccompanied and Separated Children (UASC), usually by month but sometimes by week.
Update frequency: Under development - models created for several countries and updated each year.
Topic *: Affected people: Refugees and persons of concern

Model name: The Joint Analysis of Disaster Exposure (JADE)
Partners involved *: OCHA (Asia-Pacific), WFP (Asia-Pacific), Pacific Disaster Centre
Geographical scope *: 20 countries supported in the Asia Pacific region
Description: Estimates the number of people likely to be in need after a sudden onset natural hazard. The JADE provides the number of people living in affected areas, the number of people living in the worst affected areas, and the number of people living in the worst affected area who were already considered "vulnerable" before the crisis.  There are a number other values and figures provided.  The spatial resolution is 1 x 1 km.
Update frequency: The initiative was launched in 2018.  The actual analysis is launched within 24 hours of a sudden onset emergency.  It is not expected to be updated during the course of an emergency.
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • Rapid assessment report for cyclone Bulbul in Bangladesh
  • Joint Analysis of Disaster Exposure for cyclone Kammuri in Philippines

Partners involved *: Brunel University London
Geographical scope *: The results cover case studies of three African countries at the moment but can be generalized to more contexts as per the authors.
Description: Flee aims to establish a tool that can (a) forecast the destinations of forcibly displaced persons, (b) estimate the effects on migration of major policy decisions such as border closures and camp relocations, (c) provide an estimation of the number of displaced persons in areas where the data collection is incomplete.
Update frequency: The first major version of Flee was established in 2017. It is updated continuously and is funded until May 2023. An updated and more realistic rule set for agent movement is expected in Q1 or Q2 2020.
Topic *: Affected people: Internally displaced persons;  Refugees and persons of concern
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Additional documentation:
• Published research article
  • Working paper with simulated data
  • Policy Recommendations

Partners involved *: Joint Research Centre of European Commission, OCHA
Description: Risk for humanitarian crisis and disasters is evaluated along three dimensions coping capacity, vulnerability and hazard. The model has global coverage, and the output is national scale.
Update frequency: It was developed in the 2014, and it is updated twice a year
Link to model code (if available): Detailed INFORM methdology
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • Methodology and example scenario calculations

Partners involved *: Danish Refugee Council, IBM
Description: The project develops a forecasting model for total forced displacement from a country 1-3 years ahead. Total forced displacement is a combination of refugees and asylum seekers outside a given country and the internally displaced in the same country.
Update frequency: The project was updated in 2019-2020 and it will be continuously updated with more countries.
Topic *: Affected people: Internally displaced persons;  Refugees and persons of concern
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Additional documentation: Published research article

Model name: The Inundation Model - Google flood forecasting model
Partners involved *: Google AI for Social Good
Geographical scope *: Pilot in India (Bihar) with extended coverage in in 2019 in the Indian subcontinent.
Description: Simulation based real time flood forecasting model. Accurate predictions of severity and locations of flooding based on AI and physics simulation. Integrated with local partners to put an active warning system in place.
Update frequency: Project started mid 2018 and latest 2019 iteration available online.
Link to model code (if available): Model details
Additional documentation:
• Published research article
  • Blog with working group details and overview

Partners involved *: African Union, Africa Risk Capacity
Description: Large umbrella effort to have better responses towards extreme weather events and natural disasters. The frameworks uses predictive analytics and innovative financing (insurance to redistribute risk and risk pooling) to respond.  Framework covers multiple disasters types: droughts, floods, diseases, and cyclones. The pure modelling efforts are ARV (Africa riskview).
Update frequency:
ARV model updated every year (sometimes for every harvest season)

Proprietary software package - access can be requested.
Link to model code (if available): Model overview
Additional documentation:
• Primary Resource
  • Model overview is available here.

Partners involved *: USAID, NASA, NOAA, USDA, USGS
Geographical scope *: 28 countries with a focus on West, Southern and East Africa
Description: Early warning and analysis of food insecurity - livelihood based model. Efforts are made to understand impacts on livelihoods, markets/sources, nutrition. A key component of monitoring is satellite based remote sensing. Mixed methods analysis (quantitative and qualitative analysis) enables FEWSNET to build reliable scenarios and Integrated Food Classification (IPC).
Update frequency: Updates may be issued every month. Consistent new datasets for all monitored countries are released every ~6 months (every harvest season)
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • Detailed Methodology

Partners involved *: World Bank
Geographical scope *: Pilot in 5 countries to be expanded to 21 additional countries
Description: The model combines qualitative, remote sensing, and data insights from multiple sources to generate a subnational signal of food insecurity at least 6 months to 1 year in advance.
Update frequency: No planned updates of the model after publication in scientific journal.
Additional documentation:
Scientific paper to be published in 2020
  • World Bank press release
  • UN OCHA collaboration FAM press release

Partners involved *: WFP and Alibaba
Description: Advanced statistical/ML system with a focus on large scale nowcasting. The hunger map is a platform that uses streams of public data from multiple sources to create a complex dynamic subnational portrait of world hunger. In places where the data is missing ML algorithms are used to make extrapolations.
Additional documentation: Official Website

Model name: Crisis Computing/ Artificial Intelligence for Digital Response
Partners involved *: Qatar Computing Research Institute
Description: Natural Language processing model which focuses on extracting disaster and emergency related information from social media messages. The objective of the model is to gain actionable information from troves of social media to inform better humanitarian response
Topic *: Coordination and context: 3W-Who is doing What Where; Affected Areas
Link to model code (if available): Code repository , partial code is published publicly.
Additional documentation:
• Resources and additional documentation
  • Publications
  • Crisis computing collaboration with UN OCHA

Partners involved *: WFP
Geographical scope *: Pilots in Niger, Afghanistan, Sudan, South Sudan, Tajikistan
Description: The objective of this system is to monitor the rehabilitation of degraded landscapes using satellite imagery and remote sensing. The AIMS model mainly monitors the degraded land which is rehabilitated with with the Food Assistance for Assets  (FFA) program. This approach gives evidence based quantifiable impacts of policy and landscape changes.
Update frequency: AIMS Model in development/pilot phase. Last public update was given in Oct 2018 for the 5 pilot countries.
Additional documentation:
• AIMS model documentation
  • Model overview can be found here.

Partners involved *: Netherlands Red Cross - 510
Description: Predictive model to identify high priority areas in the wake of a natural disaster. The model uses a large numbers of factors to assess this including but not limited to socio-economic factors, housing types, impact data and administrative boundaries.
Update frequency: One fully validated model for Philippines available. Pilots in development to test model scale ability in Mozambique.
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts to run the model.
Additional documentation:
• Modeling Details included in the press release
  • Output datasets and additional details for other typhoons such as Haiyan, Rammasun, Hagupit and Glenda also available

Partners involved *: National Agency for Meteorology and Environmental Monitoring (NAMEM)
Description: Each year, National Agency for Meteorology and Environmental Monitoring (NAMEM) publishes Dzud risk map which uses summer condition, pasture carrying capacity, livestock number, anomalous precipitation and temperature, snow depth, biomass, drought index, temperature forecast etc. to predict which regions may experience severe winter condition.
Link to model code (if available): Overview of Methodology
Additional documentation:
• Forecast-Based Financing for the Mongolian Druz
  • Latest report Mongolia: Dzud - Jan 2020
  • Published research looking at the causal links between drought and dzud in Mongolia

Partners involved *: REACH
Description: A model is build using high resolution data sets to account for topographical features, normalized vegetation index (NDVI), rainfall, drainage,  land cover and soil type. These factors are combined in a weighted linear fashion to compute an area's flood susceptibility (not risk).
Update frequency: Static model updated last in June 2019
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • Flood Susceptibility - Analysis Methodology

Partners involved *: IDMC, UNDRR, ETH Zurich
Description:
The model combines probabilistic analysis of events recorded in national loss databases (retrospective risk) with probabilistic risk estimates for low-frequency, high-impact events (prospective risk).
Prospective disaster displacement risk is expressed as a function of hazard, exposure and vulnerability:
Risk = Exposure x Hazard x Vulnerability
The prospective risk profile is calculated using hazard scenarios provided by a wide range of partners. These events represent all of the possible disasters that could affect a country over different return periods. For each grid cell in the exposure map, which has a resolution of between 1km x 1km in coastal areas to 5km x 5km inland, the expected impact of a hazard is calculated using vulnerability curves to determine an expected level of damage to homes and other structures based on the hazard’s intensity. Whenever the simulated damage to a home is more than 55 per cent, it is considered uninhabitable and the household displaced.
Update frequency: Model developed in 2018 using from the 2015 Global Assessment Report (https://www.preventionweb.net/english/hyogo/gar/2015/en/home/ )
Link to model code (if available): Model
Additional documentation:
• Main publication
  • Visualisation dashboard

Partners involved *: IDMC, Climate Interactive
Description: System dynamics (a modelling technique often used to analyse population dynamics and the behaviour of complex systems) is used to understand displacement dynamics of pastoralists in the Horn of Africa. The model formalises the causal relationships and drivers of pastoralist displacement, providing a decision support tool to explore the impact of specific policies and interventions. The model user interface is designed to answer a decision-maker’s “what if?” questions.
Additional documentation: Published research paper

Partners involved *: University of Florida and University of Maryland
Description: The algorithm uses precipitation, temperature, and population data from different data sources to project the risk of a cholera outbreak 4 weeks later. The risk values represent the conditions under which Vibrio’s are more likely to grow. Cholera risk increases if a region experiences a two month above average air temperature, followed by one month of above average precipitation. These two conditions must be accompanied by damage to WASH infrastructure, further facilitating interaction of cholera bacteria with humans and thereby leading to an outbreak.
Update frequency: Daily, weekly and monthly updates available
Additional documentation:
• Satellite based assessment of Hydroclimatic Conditions Related to Cholera in Zimbabwe
  • Cholera in Haiti following Hurricane Matthew
  • Risk of Cholera lessons Learned from the 2015 Nepal Earthquake

Partners involved *: Peace Research Institute Oslo (PRIO)
Description: Modelling effort that predicts internal armed conflict in a country. The scope of the study ranges from 1970 to 2050. The model uses a wide range of predictors from conflict history, development indicators of the country, neighborhood stability. The model subsequently goes through extensive testing and validation exercises.
Link to model code (if available): Model
Additional documentation:
• Published research articlePredicting Armed Conflict, 2010–2050
  • Official Website

Partners involved *: Uppsala University - Department of Peace and Conflict Research
Description: An early warning system to track and predict three classes of political violence. The model can predict armed conflict involving states and rebel groups, armed conflict between non-state actors, and violence against civilians. More importantly the model can disaggregate results into three different levels of analysis. We can analyse violence at national level, subnational level and actor level. The model takes into account a large array of input variable including but not limited to history of conflict, political institute, economic development, temporal factors, demography, natural resources and proximity of conflict.
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • Methodology
  • Evaluation
  • Peer reviewed publication
  • Current predictions dashboard

Model name: Conflict Early Warning and Response Mechanism (CEWARN)
Partners involved *: Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD)
Geographical scope *: Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Uganda
Description: Information of conflicts, migrants and natural disasters is shared between participating countries in a transparent manner. Thus information about potentially violent situations are jointly analysed to develop case scenarios and optimal responses. The analysis, data and response options are also communicated  to all IGAD member states
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • Brochure

Partners involved *: The International Crisis Group
Description: Crisis watch is a "nowcasting" tool that is updated every month to get an overview of security and political developments across 80 countries in almost real time. The tool provides a bird eye view of ongoing conflict trends, escalations and developmental impact for all decision makers.
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • Additional details

Partners involved *: Simon-Skjodt Center and Dartmouth College
Description: The statistical model of this project computes risk of mass killing and genocide by studying previous episodes (1945- present) to identify predictors and risk factors. Various models are cross validated and the best performing ones are then used to make predictions for the next two years. The output of a model is an estimated risk (of an onset of a mass killing) and the country's vulnerability rank.
Link to model code (if available): Methodology for Generating Statistical Risk Assessment
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • Map of Statistical Risk

Partners involved *: Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, UN OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data
Geographical scope *: Completed: Afghanistan, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Iraq, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan.
Description: The OCHA-Bucky model consists of a series of adjustments to an existing COVID-19 model (JHUAPL-Bucky) that was developed as part of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) COVID-19 Mathematical Modeling Forecasting Ensemble. OCHA-Bucky is a collection of coupled and stratified SEIR models. Since COVID-19 exhibits heavily age-dependent properties, wherein a majority of severe cases are in older individuals, SEIR models are stratified via the age demographic structure of a geographic region to obtain accurate estimates of case severity and deaths. Additionally, to model the spatial dynamics of COVID spread, we consider a set of SEIR sub-models at the smallest geographic level for which we have appropriate data. For a full description of the methodology please refer to the OCHA-Bucky methodology paper.
Update frequency: The Centre is producing bi-weekly reports with projections and observations for each country.
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Additional documentation:
• Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
  • Technical documentation and FAQs, explaining how to configure and run the source code in the repository.
  • Methodology paper, providing details on model assumptions and the main equations.
  • Biweekly reports for six countries
  • OCHA-Bucky model card according to the Centre's Peer Review Framework.

Partners involved *:
Imperial College London,
WHO Collaborating Centre for Infectious Disease Modelling,
MRC Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis,
Abdul Latif Jameel Institute for Disease and Emergency Analytics
Description:
Stochastic individual-based simulation model that uses population movements between households, schools, workplaces, and the community to estimate transmission. Healthcare demand and the effects of non-pharmaceutical interventions are estimated. 
Key Results: Total number of infections; expected deaths; hospitalizations; scenario building
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Main contacts: Patrick Walker Charles Whittaker Oliver Watson

Partners involved *: Imperial College London
Description: A study of age-stratified data from mainland China that estimates duration from onset-of-symptoms to death or hospital discharge, and case fatality rate.
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Main contacts: Robert Verity Lucy C Okell Ilaria Dorigatti

Partners involved *: Georgetown University Center for Global Health Science and Security, Stanford University Clinical Excellence Research Center, Grand Rounds
Description:
Open source model based on SEIR model used to provide state-specific projections of infection rates and ICU bed usage. Subnational projections for USA are reported. Dashboards for data visualization and APIs to explore all datasets available. 
Key Results: Total number of infections; expected deaths; hospitalizations; scenario building

Korea; Moldova; Romania; Russia; Serbia; Slovenia; Spain; Sweden; Turkey; Ukraine; United Kingdom; USA

Partners involved *:
MIDAS Coordination Center
Penn State University
Description: This is a decision theoretic framework that takes in results from multiple individual models to produce a unified set of projections and recommendations. By taking into account multiple modelling efforts decision makers can avoid cognitive biases, and insights from many different modeling approaches can be included.
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • Published research- Harnessing multiple models for outbreak management

Partners involved *:
MIDAS Coordination Center
University of Massachusetts at Amherst
Description: The ensemble forecast dashboard combines multiple models; unconditional on particular interventions being in place with those conditional on certain social distancing measures continuing. 21+ different models with 4 week-ahead forecasts ahead are included in the ensemble and their weekly predictions are visualized on the dashboard.
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Additional documentation: Forecast Hub

Model name: Nowcasting model for real time epidemic tracking
Partners involved *:
MIDAS Coordination Center
Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Description: Nowcasting model here attempts to estimate the complete case counts for a given reporting date, using a time series of case reporting that is known to be incomplete due to reporting delays. The model uses  Bayesian Smoothing, accounts for serial autocorrelation and gives output estimates that are smooth and accurate in multiple disease settings.
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Main contacts:
• Sarah F. McGough
  • Nicolas A. Menzies
Additional documentation: Published research Nowcasting for epidemic tracking

Model name: Stochastic model for the transmission of 2019-nCov in Wuhan
Partners involved *: Center for the Ecology of Infectious Diseases, University of Georgia
Description:
Stochastic SEIR based model that includes additional time-varying rates of case detection, patient isolation, and case notification parameters. By using forward simulation, the model enables the generation of predictions about the future trajectory of the epidemic under alternative scenarios for containment. The model parameters have been calibrated using multiple different input sources.
Key Results: Total number of infections; scenario building
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Additional documentation: Official Website

Model name: Scenario analysis for the transmission of COVID‑19
Partners involved *: Center for the Ecology of Infectious Diseases, University of Georgia
Description:
Stochastic SEIR based model which is employed for location- Georgia USA for scenario building under various interventions such as increased social distancing, increased hygiene, against returning to normal.  
Key Results: Total number of infections; expected deaths; hospitalizations; scenario building
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Additional documentation: • Official Website

Model name: Gravity model for spread of 2019-nCov in China
Partners involved *: Center for the Ecology of Infectious Diseases, University of Georgia
Description: Gravity-based model the risk of spatial spread of the 2019-nCov at the admin2 (prefecture) level in China, and to determine the efficacy of quarantines and travel restrictions imposed in Wuhan and other prefectures.
Additional documentation: Official Website

Partners involved *: Center for the Ecology of Infectious Diseases, University of Georgia
Description:
The model attempts to project the potential size of the COVID-19 outbreak by repurposing a previously developed Ebola model. This model can provide global ballpark figures of worse, worst, average case scenarios. Ongoing work on this model includes parametrization to have more region specific insight. 
Key Results: Total number of infections; scenario building
Main contacts:
• John M. Drake
  • Andrew W. Park
Additional documentation: • Official Website

Partners involved *: Center for the Ecology of Infectious Diseases, University of Georgia
Description: This model assesses the impact of a symptom-based mass screening and testing intervention during a novel infectious disease outbreak in China.
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Main contacts:
• Yang Ge
  • Brian McKay
  • Shengzhi Sun
Additional documentation: Published research Assessing the impact of a symptom-based mass screening

Partners involved *: Center for the Ecology of Infectious Diseases, University of Georgia
Description:
This model aims to nowcast the number of latent and symptomatic infections from a point in the past forward to the present. The authors accomplish this by fitting a time varying autoregressive model, and then forecast the fitted model curve using an exponential smoothing (ETS) model. The model works to determine the ratio of detected cases to the true number of cases i.e the ascertainment rate.
Key Results: Total number of infections
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Additional documentation: Official Website

Model name: SARS-CoV-2 mortality during the early stages of an epidemic
Partners involved *:
Institute of Social and Preventive Medicine, University of Bern
Columbia University
Imperial College London
Geographical scope *: Hubei, China; Austria; Baden-Württemberg (Germany); Lombardy (Italy); Spain; Switzerland
Description:
This study attempts to simulate the transmission dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 using publicly available surveillance data. The model is then used to infer estimates of SARS-CoV-2 mortality, adjusted for biases.  It also examines the case fatality ratio (CFR), the symptomatic case fatality ratio (sCFR) and the infection fatality ratio (IFR) in different geographic locations.
Key Results: Total number of infections
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.

  • Michel Counotte
  • Charles C. Margossian

Model name: Estimating unobserved SARS-CoV-2 infections in the United States
Partners involved *: University of Notre Dame
Description: This model aims to estimate the extent of community transmission of SARS-CoV-2 in the US that occurred prior to its widespread recognition. The extent of community transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is estimated using a stochastic simulation model that combined importation and local transmission processes.

Model name: Real-time forecasting of infectious disease dynamics
Partners involved *: London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine
Description: A Bayesian semi-mechanistic SEIR model of infectious diseases, that was used in real time during the 2013–2016 West African Ebola epidemic is presented. This model can be used for real-time forecasting of infectious diseases. Specific SARS-CoV-2 projections are not a part of this model at this stage.
Link to model code (if available): Code repository, including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.

Partners involved *:
Northeastern University,
Bruno Kessler Foundation,
ISI Foundation
Description: The authors use a global metapopulation disease transmission model (GLEAM) to project the impact of travel limitations on the national and international spread of the epidemic. The model is calibrated on the basis of internationally reported cases. The outputs are multiple dashboards which track the number of cases and risk of virus importation

Model name: Machine Learning the Phenomenology of COVID-19
Partners involved *: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute
Description: Data-driven machine learning analysis of the COVID-19 pandemic from its early infection dynamics, specifically infection counts over time. The goal of this model is to project the infectious force i.e the rate of a mild infection becoming serious. Additionally the model estimates asymptomatic infections and makes overall predictions of new infections over time
Additional documentation: Published researchMachine Learning the Phenomenology of COVID-19

Model name: CORVID: Modeling layered non-pharmaceutical interventions against SARS-CoV-2
Partners involved *:
Institute for Disease Modeling,
Patient Knowhow Inc.
Description: Covid is an individual-based model that simulates the spread of SARS-CoV-2 in synthetic populations that represent communities in the United States.This model  can be used to understand the potential effectiveness of non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) for both suppression and mitigation efforts.
Link to model code (if available): Code repository , including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.

Model name: CHIME (COVID-19 Hospital Impact Model for Epidemics)
Partners involved *: Penn Medicine, University of Pennsylvania
Description:
The CHIME model and web app is designed to assist hospitals and public health officials with understanding hospital capacity in response to the COVID pandemic. The model outputs provide estimates of total daily and running totals of inpatient hospitalizations, ICU admissions, and patients requiring ventilation. The model is built using a SIR (Susceptible, Infected, Recovered) epidemiological model. 
Key Results: Total number of infections; expected deaths; hospitalizations; scenario building
Link to model code (if available): Code repository , including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • Webtool and links to additional documentation

Partners involved *: Covid-19 International Modelling Consortium (CoMo Consortium)
Description:
The CoMo model is a simulation based tool designed to emulate multiple scenarios,impacts of non pharmacological interventions, to make reliable estimates and predictions about the spread, hospitalizations and deaths related to COVID-19. There are a range of input parameter values to customize simulations. Although explicit modeling parameters have not been made public it is being used extensively by decision makers where explicit country based models do not exist. 
Key Results: Total number of infections; expected deaths; hospitalizations; scenario building
Link to model code (if available): Code repository , including all the source code scripts necessary to run the model.

• Olivier Celhay
  • Ricardo Aguas
  • Lisa White
  • Sai Thein Than Tun

Partners involved *: Future of Humanity Institute, University of Oxford
Description:
The epidemic forecasting model and online tool can be used to calculate the estimated effect of various combinations of COVID countermeasures. Multiple parameters and compliance rates can be adjusted by decision makers. The output of the model is effective reproduction number which is the expected number of infections directly generated by one additional infection. This model works in conjunction with the GLEAM model (also in the catalogue)
Key Results: Total number of infections; scenario building
Additional documentation: Website

Partners involved *: WFP and local governments
Geographical scope *: Algeria, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Egypt, Georgia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Lebanon, Libya, Moldova, Morocco, Oman, Russian Federation, Saudi Arabia, State of Palestine, Sudan , Syria, Tajikistan, Tunisia, Turkey, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Yemen
Description: The Food Prices Early Warning is done using an indicator that monitors the extent to which a local food experiences abnormally high food price levels. Food price crises are correlated with food security crises. Early detection of rising prices supports decision making and early action. Early warnings allow WFP, governments and other partners to be aware of the latest trends of food prices and take appropriate actions to absorb any expected shock. The Shock Impact Simulation is done through a macroeconomic modelling system called SISMod that brings new possibilities to allow timely quantitative assessments on the ex-ante and ex-post impact of various types of shocks (market, economic, sociopolitical, climatic, etc.) on household vulnerability. It identifies and profiles vulnerable groups, estimating to what extent they are in need. The model outputs are focussed on early warning and shock impacts.

Partners involved *: Kartoza and Red Cross Red Crescent Climate Centre
Description: Impact based Forecasting - The impact based forecast functionality in the  InaSAFE platform will generate an estimate of districts, number of people and houses likely to be affected in the event of a flood with certain return period. It uses GLOFAS, JRC, OSM, and WorldPop as main sources of data. The model has the potential to cover all river basins in the country, for the moment focuses on the ones where there are measuring stations. The lead time provided is between 10 to 3 days, as per GLOFAS forecast. The model is to be used by Indonesia Red Cross as part of its Forecast-based Action system for floods.
Update frequency: 2019,  to be updated in 2020 when no data is available
Link to model code (if available): Code repository
Main contacts:
• Tim Sutton
  • Catalina Jaime
Additional documentation: Official Website

Model name: CALM, the Cholera Artificial Learning Model
Partners involved *: The International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) Foundation
Description: Cholera Artificial Learning Model (CALM) creates a system of four extreme-gradient-boosting (XGBoost) machine learning models that, in tandem, forecast the exact number (with an error margin of 4.787 cases per 10,000) of cholera cases any given Yemeni governorate will experience for multiple time intervals ranging from 2 weeks to 2 months. Details about features engineering, model tuning and results are publicly available.
Link to model code (if available): Code repository

Partners involved *:
University of Florida
National Aeronautics and Space Administration
Description: This model uses satellite and ground-based data to forecast the risk of cholera in Yemen and other countries. The map linked alongside shows the forecasted risk of cholera in Yemen from August 10 to September 6, 2020. It was created with the Cholera Prediction Modeling System, which incorporates NASA precipitation data, air temperature data from NASA’s MERRA-2 reanalysis product, and population data. The number of cholera cases could increase in coming weeks, influenced by heavy rains that usually fall in August, though researchers predict the outbreaks should be limited to a few hotspots unless there is a large population displacement. The model got its first real-world test in 2017, and achieved 92 percent accuracy in predicting areas where cholera appeared that year.
Additional documentation:
• Latest NASA blog on model updates
  • NASA blogpost

Model name: Using Predictive Analytics to Identify Children at High Risk of Defaulting From a Routine Immunization Program
Partners involved *: Child Health and Vaccines program, Interactive Research and Development (IRD)
Description: This predictive analytics algorithm is designed to identify the children who are likely to default on subsequent immunization visits. 47,554 longitudinal immunization records, which were classified into the training and validation cohorts. Four machine learning models (random forest; recursive partitioning; support vector machines, SVMs; and C-forest) were used to generate the algorithm that predicts the likelihood of each child defaulting from the follow-up immunization visit. Each of the models was assessed in terms of accuracy, precision (positive predictive value), sensitivity, specificity and negative predictive value, and area under the curve (AUC) and is seen to perform reasonably. This model demonstrates that predictive analytics can accurately identify children who are at a higher risk for defaulting on follow-up immunization visits and could be targeted for additional interventions.
Main contacts:
• Subhash Chandir
  • Danya Arif Siddiqi
  • Owais Ahmed Hussain
Additional documentation: Published peer reviewed research on feasibility study for the project

Model name: Platform for Real-time Impact and Situation Monitoring (PRISM)
Partners involved *:
World Food Program
Japan Government
USAID
Geographical scope *: Global - Indonesia, Sri Lanka, and Cambodia, while deployments to Mongolia and Afghanistan are forthcoming
Description: PRISM enables WFP’s partners in government and WFP country offices to access the latest available climate hazard information alongside vulnerability data through an intuitive, map-based dashboard. PRISM combines information from satellites and other remote sensing sources with WFP data on vulnerability to create actionable climate information for decision makers, allowing them to prioritize assistance to those most in need.PRISM is capable of producing impact-based forecasts: converting climate information into programming which focuses on the socioeconomic impact of a hazard.
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • PRISM Model output for Mongolia
  • WFP blog post

Partners involved *: Mercy Corps
Description: M-RED will use drone technology to measure and monitor land to take more effective preemptive measures against land degradation and floods in Nepal (pilot). By observing targeted areas, the program should accurately detect and track land use changes. The data and predictive analytics are used to model floods and track shifting rivers and are designed to will benefit target communities. Model performance and details are documented but code is not public.
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • Official Detailed Documentation
  • Mercy Corps Blogpost
  • Blogpost with model results

Model name: Predicting Demographic Trends for Global UNHCR Persons of Concern
Partners involved *: UNHCR
Description: The Demographic Projection Tool (DPTool) used uses data that are already available to UNHCR field operations. This model uses the demographic balancing equation to simulate different scenarios about the future size and composition of the refugee population.The tool at the moment only works well if the contextual conditions of a humanitarian emergency remain the same. The DPTool is better-suited for short-term projections in its current iteration. The tool also continues to rely heavily on UNHCR personnel who must define the parameters of the model based on their expert knowledge of the situation on the field.
Additional documentation:
• DPT Tool Official Website
  • Non-Peer reviewed paper
  • UNHCR Blogpost

Model name: Modelling Early Risk Indicators to Anticipate Malnutrition (MERIAM)
Partners involved *: Action Against Hunger, the Graduate Institute of Geneva, John Hopkins University, and the University of Maryland.
Description: MERIAM deploys a complementary combination of innovative methodologies – both econometric and computational modelling – and leverages a variety of existing and accessible data sets to rigorously capture causal factors of acute malnutrition. Taken together, these aspects allow the project to dynamically model the fluctuation of acute malnutrition in contexts where this information is most urgently required. By better understanding the leading risk factors for acute malnutrition, MERIAM can forecast who may be most at-risk of becoming wasted, when they are likely to become wasted, and where (in what geographical area they reside).
Additional documentation:
• Official Website
  • Additional information
  • Briefing note

Partners involved *: Digital Impact Alliance (DIAL), Cooper/Smith
Description: In 2020 Cooper/Smith developed a population mobility model in Malawi with the support of the Digital Impact Alliance (DIAL) and the Malawi Ministry of Health (MoH). The mobility model provides insight on population localization and movement patterns, enabling the MoH and local stakeholders to have a near real-time view on where the population is, providing a much-needed complement to the census.
Link to model code (if available): N/A
Main contacts:
• Guillaume Foutry, Program Manager for West Africa
  • Cassie Morgan, Sustainability Coordinator, Kuunika Project, Malawi
  • Coopersmith
Additional documentation: Final report of the peer review process conducted by the Centre according to the OCHA’s Peer Review Framework.

Partners involved *: ACLED
Description: The ACLED Conflict Alert System (CAST) is a global prediction tool that forecasts the number of political violence events that will occur each month, for the next six months, in every country around the world. Specifically, the tool predicts the ACLED battles, explosions/remote violence, and violence against civilians event types at the country and subnational first administrative division (i.e. province) level, in addition to producing an overall global forecast. The forecasts are made using a host of measures including historical events, events in neighboring areas, types of actor interactions, and recent strategic developments. All results are available for download as an Excel file or via an API.
Update frequency: New predictions are published each month for the following six months, alongside accuracy metrics for previous forecasts.
